iati-activity.title: Parliamentary Strengthening
iati-activity.description: The project aims to support the parliament in the four main areas of its constitutional responsibility: lawmaking, setting policy direction, executive oversight, and representation.

document-link.title: 00057935 Strengthening the System of Parliamentary Democracy in Georgia 2014-2016 EU
00057935 Strong Parliament in a Consolidated Democracy 20102013 NETH

iati-activity.title: Parliamentary Democracy System
iati-activity.description: Increased Functionality of the Parliament.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Availability of Parliament's Institutional Reform Plan (IRP). 2. New mandate for the Parliament's international relations services. 3. Citizen-oriented public outreach activities. Number of Parliament's commitments in Open Government Partnership (OGP). 4. Number of amendments to parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP), including alignment with the latest constitutional changes. 5. Terms of Reference for donor coordination system in place and operational. 6. Number of committee action plans in place and operational. 7. Number of staff trainings on legislative and financial monitoring functions (summoning committee meetings, conducting government hearings, organizing public sessions, scrutinizing program budgets, utilizing budget execution and State Audit reports, etc.) 8. Action plan and communications roadmap of Committee on European integration in place and operational. Number of staff trainings on legal harmonization and overall integration issues; knowledge-sharing activities (study visits, conferences) with EU Member States. 9. Number of public outreach activities (Europe Day celebration, media workshops, etc.) on European integration processes.

baseline.comment: 1. The Parliament of Georgia lacks a vision of its development strategy. 2. Insufficient structured approach to international relations. Respective parliamentary services perform only protocol functions. 3. The Parliament's public trust is not sufficient. It lacks transparency and adequate public outreach. 4. Parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP) are not realigned with the latest constitutional amendments. 5. Donor coordination in the Parliament remains ineffective. 6. Parliamentary committees lack strategic approach to exercising their constitutional functions. 7. Law-making and oversight capacities of parliamentary committees remain weak. 8. There is a cross-party consensus in favour of Georgia's accelerated European integration; however, both Members and staff of the Parliament lack sufficient knowledge of European issues. 9. There is a low public awareness on Georgia-European Union relations, where the Parliament has a decisive role to play.

target.comment: 1. Parliament's 2013 needs assessment updated. Institutional Reform Plan developed and approved. 2. Draft Concept on Parliament's International Relations prepared. 3. Parliament's communications strategy updated. Communications action plan drafted and approved. 5. New donor coordination mechanism developed and approved. 6. Needs assessment of the selected parliamentary committees conducted. Strategic action plans developed and approved for four selected sector committees. 7. Baseline studies of the selected committees in the area of law-making and budgetary oversight conducted. At least 4 trainings and workshops for committee staff delivered in the mentioned areas. 8. Needs assessment of the Committee on European Integration (CEI) conducted. CEI action plan and communications roadmap developed and approved. CEI staff capacity development plan developed.

actual.comment: 1. Parliament's 2013 needs assessment is updated but Institutional Reform Plan has not been finalized. 2. Draft concept on Parliament's international relations is prepared in consultation with the Parliament. 3. Parliament's communications strategy is updated, but communications action plan has not been finalized. Parliament staff participated in study visits to Croatia and Estonia to inform the process of action plan development. 4. N/A 5. Terms of Reference for donor coordination has been developed and agreed with the Parliament. 6. Needs assessment of the selected parliamentary committees have been conducted. Based on the needs assessment, strategic action plans have been produced for all four committees. 7. Baseline studies of selected committees have been conducted. Using the findings of the studies, training programs have been designed. Over 8 different trainings and workshops have been organized for the committee staff. 8. Needs assessment of the Committee on European Integration (CEI) has been conducted. Based on assessment, the draft action plan and communications roadmap have been produced. Draft capacity development plan has been also prepared. CEI members and staff participated in the study visit to Latvia. 9. Explanatory videos on European Union-Georgia Association Agreement (AA) have been prepared and aired on different media outlets. High school student competition has been organized. Europe Day has been celebrated in the Parliament of Georgia. Workshop with media on AA was organized.

target.comment: 1. Institutional Reform Plan finalized and adopted by the Parliament. 2. Concept on International relations agreed with the Parliament; respective amendments to the parliamentary regulations made. 3. Communications strategy developed. Open Parliament Georgia Action Plan developed. 4. Amendments to Parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP) initiated 5. Newly introduced donor coordination mechanism operational. 6. All 4 strategic action plans of the committees are operational. 7. Parliamentary staff , including from targeted sector committees have greater capacities for fulfilling their duties 8. Action plan of the Committee on European Integration (CEI), communications roadmap and capacity development plan finalized. .

indicator.title: Output Indicator

baseline.comment: Over the past years the Government of Georgia developed and introduced system changes in many sectors, aided by international partners including UNDP and Sida. The country, however, confronts requirement to further improve public administration, which in its turn requires advancement of capacities within the public sector. Public agencies still largely lack institutional, individual or financial capacities to design the long term vision and implement coherent measures to achieve their goals. Assistance in this direction shall bring sustainable capacity development impact for the government.

iati-activity.title: On Demand Support
iati-activity.description: The ODS mechanism of the GRF project implies on-demand provision of a combination of national and international advisory services.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1/ # of farmers received consultations and services of extension center 1.2/ # of innovations disseminated and applied by means of Extension Service provider. 1.3/ # of farmers trained in agri-business skills 1.4/ accessibility of green house for demonstration sessions and accessibility of seedlings for local farmers 1.5/ Accessibility of practical and theoretical knowledge, appropriate inventory and facility for local farmers 2.1/ availability of results of market survey 2.2/ availability of fruit dryer 2.3/ # of local farmers using fruit druer 2.4/ # of demonstration sessions provided at Gori University Dairy Plant. 3.1/ availability of market information on off season fresh products 3.2/ links established between fresh fruit buyers and famers 3.3/ availability of new cold storage facilities. 5.1/ # of inputs delivered and # of demonstration plots arranged 6.1/ # kindergarten building rehabilitated, renovated and operational 6.2/ # of water systems installed and operational

baseline.comment: 1.1/ No regular and institutionalized extension services accessible to all vulnerable communities; 1.2/ No facilities and formats for initiation of innovative methods in farming are available in the area. 1.3/ No agri-business training provided to farmers 1.4/No enough green houses operate in the region serving for demonstration needs and providing local farmers with seedlings 1.5/ No enough beekeeping farms operates and no trainings and education provided in this field in the region 2.1/ No high quality market information on dried fruits 2.2/No template design of simple fruit dryer available for farmers 2.3/ Lack of fruit drying facilities available for local farmers 2.4/ Lack of practical demonstration possibilities available for local farmers in processing 3.1/ Lack of market information on market for fresh off season products. 3.2/ No regular links between fresh fruit buyers and farmers. 3.4 / Lack of availability of cold storages. 5.1/ Lack of agriculture facilities and inputs in the area 6.1/ No modern and unsafe kindergarten existing 6.2/ No drinking water system existing in the selected area

target.comment: 1.5/ At least 20 farmers trained in Gori Vocational College in beekeeping farming 5.1.1/ Assessment of needs of farmers of selected area conducted 5.1.2/ At list 30 farm upgrade (demonstration projects) are developed (o/w 20 in beekeeping) and arranged according to modern intensive agriculture technologies 5.1.3/ At least 180 farmers received inputs and relevant advises for farming activity. 6.1/ At least 40 children from 2 villages of Kareli municipality benefit annually from improved kindergarten facility 6.2/ Drinking water systems installed and operational in at least 4 villages in selected area and in Dvani kindergarten

actual.comment: 1.5/ 4-month vocational training in beekeeping for self-employed of Kaspi Municipality was provided to 20 beneficiary families, as well as all necessary equipment for start-up of business activity in beekeeping . 5.1.1/ Assessment of the needs of the farmers from 6 villages (Karafila, Saribari, Zadiaantkari, Sakorintlo, Tvaurebi and Metekhi IDP settlement) of Kaspi Municipality was conducted, which revealed that farmers are in need of primary agricultural inputs (seedlings of main vegetable varieties) and agricultural training. 5.1.2/ Total of 30 demonstration plots were set up in the farms of local farmers, o/w 20 in beekeeping and 10 in vegetable and fruit (berries) growing. 5.1.3/ More than 145,500 vegetable seedlings (tomato, pepper and eggplants), 20 tons of wheat seedlings and fertilizers delivered to up to 270 beneficiaries in above-mentioned 6 villages, plus villages Kodistskaro and Goraka at the request of the local authorities and population for the purpose of private use and for the demonstration plots. 6.1/ Project has rehabilitated kindergarten in the village of Dvani (Kareli municipality), which serves to 50 children from 2 villages (Takhtisdziri and Dvani). Kindergarten was fully rehabilitated (roof, windows, flooring, electric wiring, sewage replaced, heating and insulation system installed, fully furnished) and sustainable source of energy (solar panels) installed, which ensures 100% running hot water, except for 4 winter months, where solar panels provide up to 80%. 6.2/ Drinking water supply systems newly arranged in 3 villages of Kaspi Municipality (Karafila, Saribari, Zadiaantkari) (including setting up of water wells, drainage, drinking water pipeline systems, reservoirs, local tips and other related works), which will allow up to 80 families residing in these villages to have direct access to drinking water as opposed to shipping water from distant single water source. Drinking water supply systems was rehabilitated in villages Sakori

target.comment:
7.1/Needs assessment for technical assistance to Information Consultation Centers conducted and relevant technical assistance provided to at least 2 Information Consultancy Centers in Shida Kartli municipalities 7.2.1/ Livelihood needs assessment of farmers of selected areas conducted to reveal most demanded vocations in the region. 7.2.2/ At least 50 farmers trained with quality vocational trainings in the most demanded agricultural vocations
8.1/ At least 270 farmers in Shida Kartli municipalities provided with farming (inputs and relevant advises (trainings) for further activity) 8.2/ At least 20 farms’ infrastructure upgraded 8.3/ At least 4 farmers cooperatives established and or supported comprised of target community members

document-link.title: Project document: Skills for Employment Phase 2

iati-activity.title: Skills for Employment-phase2
iati-activity.description: The overall objective of this phase (2014-2015) is to contribute to incorporating/formalising the VET re-training system into the formal VET system as an additional impetus for improving employability of the labour force.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1/ The Concept for incorporating vocational retraining into a formal Vocational Education and Training (VET) system and tested in selected two colleges. 2/ Conceptual vision for application of software and other teaching methodologies in VET and its piloting in selected two colleges 3/ A conceptual vision and plan is developed for application of internal QI systems and their testing in selected colleges 4/ The methodology for employment programmes design and national institutional set-up design for their implementation is available

baseline.comment: 1/ No concept exist for incorporating vocational retraining into a formal Vocational and Education Training (VET) system 2/ No vision and feasible plan for application of soft and other digital teaching technologies in VET 3/ No conceptual vision and feasible plan for improving under-developed internal quality management system in VET colleges 4/ No Employment Supporting Programmes design methodology and national institutional set-up for implementing demand driven employment supporting programmes exist

target.comment: 1/ Piloting of vocational retraining schemes in selected two colleges (for at least 100 beneficiaries, of which at least 10% women). 2/ Testing and piloting new software application in two selected colleges. 3/ The conceptual vision and plan for application of internal Quality Management (QM) systems is developed and QM systems application is supported in selected two colleges. 4/ Newly developed programmes are piloted and their impact is assessed in selected colleges (for at least 110 beneficiaries, of which at least 10% women).

actual.comment: 1/ Vocational retraining schemes are being piloted in two colleges (Iberia - Kuutaisi and Phazisi - Poti). Nearly 50 students applied out of which 8% is women 2/ Trainings of teachers are undergoing for application of the new software in colleges. 3/ The internal Quality Management (QM) systems application recommendations are developed. QM systems are applied in two colleges (Iberia and Phazisi). 4/ Newly developed Vocational Training programs linked to employment scheme is undergoing (for 50 students out of which 8% women). The impact assessment will be performed in the IV Q of 2015

iati-activity.title: Skills for Agriculture-SDC
iati-activity.description: The proposed project aims to contribute to the development of a system of high quality vocational training and extension services in agriculture that will result in improved livelihoods of the rural population.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1: # of students trained, re-trained in agriculture and farmers benefited from extension services 1.2: # of institutions where environment improved 1.3: # of institutions and staff members which capacities were developed 2.1: # of professional standards revised/developed, teaching materials for teachers trainers and teachers trained 2.2: # of professions for which the VET teaching materials are developed, students and teachers trained 3.1: # of reforms in supported in VET in agriculture, assessments and cooperation mechanism between MoES and MoA. 3.2: private and public stakeholders are involved in provision of VET and extension services 3.3: Institutionalized format of national coordination and cooperation between the private and public sector in VET in agriculture and extension operational

baseline.comment: 1.1: Lack of accessibility of flexible Vocational Education and Training (VET) in agriculture and extension services. 1.2: Underdeveloped learning infrastructure. 1.3: weak capacities of VET colleges and extension centres to deliver teaching and training in agriculture and agricultural extension 2.1: The system of continuous VET teachers’ skills development and extension workers does not exist Indicator: # of professional standards revised/developed, teaching materials for teachers trainers and teachers trained 2.2: The system of VET for agricultural sector service providers is underdeveloped 3.1: There is the need for new policy on development of VET in agriculture and Extension services 3.3: Lack of engagement of private and public stakeholders in provision of VET in agriculture and extension 3.3: Lack of cooperation between private and public sector and nationally accessible

target.comment: 1.1/ Target 10 specialised farmers trained /year/college; 1,200 farmers benefit from trainings; 3,500 farmers benefit from extension services1 model of VET officially endorsed 1.2/Target: infrastructure in 5 colleges & 7 extension centers developed 1.3/ Target: 4 colleges & 4 Extension centres have developed plans & strategies; 3 college staff trained 2.2/ Target: 5 VET colleges offer courses in agriculture; 15 students/college/year trained; 20 retrained teachers; 3.2 Target Umbrella organisation of farmers is established. Private stakeholders are engaged in training 3.3 Target. Platform has been set up and is operational

actual.comment: 1.1 The VET colleges in Ambrolauri, Kachreti, Akhaltsikhe, Telavi and Zugdidi University are providing updated agricultural professional programmes and current and futures farmers are trained in those colleges. In 2014, 10 farmers per colleges have been trained based on specialized programmes. In addition, about 1000 farmers benefited for short term trainings, provided as non-formal training courses at the colleges. Those trainings where implemented based on needs assessment and newly designed training programmes. 1.2 The project supported the development of infrastructure in 5 colleges, mainly with specialized equipment for agricultural workshops. The project supported the colleges with machinery and tools like: disinfection units, portable ultrasound machine, drip and sprinkler irrigation system for small plots, grain crusher, grape press, vine grafting electrical device and bactofuge. Those workshops have been not only used for educational programmes, training and extension activities have been also developed at the premises of those 5 colleges. 1.3 The VET colleges in Ambrolauri, Kachreti, Akhaltsikhe, Telavi and Zugdidi University have developed own strategic plans and published then on their own websites. They contain as well information about college based extension activities. 2.2 The VET colleges in Ambrolauri, Kachreti, Akhaltsikhe, Telavi and Zugdidi University (Senaki Branch) are offering updated agricultural programmes. The colleges are preparing for implementation of 8 modular programmes in agriculture starting with 2015. Teachers are under ongoing trainings for new program implementation. More than 15 students / college / year are trained. 3.2 Private stakeholders, mostly farmers, are prepared to participate in the newly planned set-up of the VET council and will be nominated for the thematic working group “Agriculture”. 3.3 The establishment of a new VET council is supported and going to be implemented in 2015. The new VET council and its thematic wo

target.comment: 1.1. 7 specialized farmers trained in each partner college; 1,200 farmers benefit from trainings in agriculture; 3,500 farmers benefit from extension services1 model of VET officially endorsed 1.2. Infrastructure in 3 colleges & 7 extension centers developed 1.3. 4 colleges & 4 Extension centers have developed plans & strategies; 2 college staff trained 2.2. 2 VET colleges offer courses in agriculture; 15 students/college/year engaged; 20 retrained teachers; 3.2 Umbrella organization responsible for farmers education is operational 3.3 National platform for coordination of VET and Extension in Agriculture is operational

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Georgia freezes HCFC22 consumption by 2013 to meet 10% and 35% reduction targets in 2015 and 2020 according to the Montreal Protocol targets.

baseline.comment: Country obligation to meet agreed targets for HCFC overall consumption reduction

target.comment: 1. Enable Georgia to meet the obligations under the Montreal Protocol to freeze HCFC22 consumption by 2013 (freeze baseline level by 2013 is 83.9 tones) and start reduction of the consumption by 2014 in order to meet 10% reduction targets in 2015 (75.51 tones) according to the Montreal Protocol targets.

actual.comment: 1. 1. Consumption of the HCFC 22 by the 2014 is 22.3 tones, which is 3 times less then target level for the 2015.

target.comment: 1. Enable Georgia to meet 10% reduction targets of the HCFC22 consumption in 2015 (75.51 tones) according to the Montreal Protocol targets.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Percentage of women at decision making positions increased 2. Increase in employment rates and earnings and decrease gap between the proportions of men's and women's employment and earning rates

target.comment:
1.a no changes expected 1.b. no changes expected 1 .c Increase women's participation in local governance to at least 15% (Local Elections scheduled in June 2014)
2.a unemployment rate women 12.5%, men 16% 2.b gender pay gap - 62 Tetri/1 GEL

actual.comment:
1.a 11.3% (17 female MPs among 150) 1.b 15.8 % (3 women ministers out of 16 Ministers and 3 State Ministers) 1.c 11.6% females took seats in local self-government in 2014 local self-governance elections .
2.a unemployment rate women 12.3%, men 16.5%, 2.b gender pay gap - 63 Tetri/1 GEL (2013 data).

target.comment:
1. no changes in 2015 targets as the 2015 is a non-electoral year
2.a unemployment rate women 12%, men 15.7% 2.b gender pay gap - 65 Tetri/1 GEL

iati-activity.title: Sustainable Pastures Management
iati-activity.description: Sustainable Management of Pastures in Georgia to Demonstrate Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation Benefits and Dividends for Local Communities

iati-activity.title: Sustainable Pastures Managemen
iati-activity.description: Rehabilitate 4,064 ha of degraded pastures in Vashlovani Protected Areas, introduce methods for migratory route rehabilitation applied in a 300 ha area and introduce/implement sustainable pasture management practices in the Dedoplistskaro region.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Sustainable pasture management plan developed and implemented 2) 300 ha migratory routes rehabilitated; 3) Local farmers knowledge in sustainable land management practices increased and SLM practices applied. 4) Pilot projects established and lessons learned extracted and disseminated. 5) Capacity of Association of sheep-breeders is improved to coordinate the activities. 6) Carbon release and sequestration monitoring established and conducted. 7) Inter-ministerial policy debate on pastures management issues initiated on national level. Key priority actions agreed. 8) Rehabilitation of 4 064 ha of degraded land. 9) Introduction of sustainable land use practices. 10) Monitoring system on climate conditions introduced 11) Introduction of new technologies. 12) Increase in productivity in piloted areas.

baseline.comment: Degraded pastures in Vashlovani Protected Areas (VPAs) 4064 ha of VPAs severely or modestly degraded4064 ha of VPAs severely or modestly degraded Local community resilience in pasturelands is low

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Biennial Update Report (BUR) completed and submitted to UNFCCC (Y/N). GHG emissions inventory report for 2010-2011 is updated and for 2012-2013 is completed.

baseline.comment: Georgia pledged to submit its first Biennial Update Report (BUR) to the UNFCCC by 2016; National Circumstance Chapter of SNC covers situation until 2012; Georgia’s GHG inventory submitted to the UNFCCC covers years until 2012; Mitigation strategy is currently being prepared under the TNC; UNEP TNA was completed in September 2012. Georgia’s First Biennial Update Report will build on the findings and recommendations of Third National Communication, as well as the outcomes of the ongoing complementary projects in the country, and will be submitted to the UNFCCC in 2016.

iati-activity.title: Tbilisi Floods-Post Disaster needs assessment
iati-activity.description: Tbilisi Floods-Post-Disaster needs assessment and risk-informed recovery

iati-activity.title: Tbilisi Floods-Post Disaster n
iati-activity.description: Tbilisi was hit by a major flash flood that wrought significant damage and caused loss of life through a large swath in the middle of the city. It was decided to assist the GoG in rapid post-disaster needs assessment for short and medium term recovery.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Recovery needs assessment report produced 2. Recovery framework developed

baseline.comment: Insufficient government capacities to conduct long-term recovery needs assessment and develop recovery framework Lack and/or insufficient hazard data for Tbilisi Lack of updated hydrological and geological hazard risk mapping of the city Limitations in coordination between donor community and the Government on implementation of the short-to medium term recovery efforts; inaccurate/ limited information of various datasets, cases of duplication of efforts; Government request to assist with the coordination

target.comment: 1. Post-disaster Recovery needs assessment conducted 2. Recovery framework and plans developed
